text: I'm Christopher gray architectural
historian and streetscapes columnist for
the New York Times every block I walk
down I'm looking for an odd detail a
strange building New York's little
mysteries it's my job to solve them the
city and its architecture is my beat in
1906 the brilliant taciturn banker J
Pierpont Morgan built this treasure
house for the books and manuscripts he
had amassed like a vacuum cleaner
rolling back and forth across Europe now
one of New York's great museums the
Morgan Library is just finishing an
interior restoration of its remarkable
rooms
his architect Charles McKim took four
years to design and finish this perfect
little Tennessee marble gym it must have
been a glorious day for Morgan when he
could finally bring his precious
collection in debris the holy air this
little temple
it includes illuminated manuscripts
drafts by authors like Blake PO Zola and
Dickens Gutenberg Bibles and a life mask
of George Washington
Morgan finished his library in 1906 and
in this crimson room study he could
smoke cigars play solitaire and enjoy
his favorite possessions which he kept
in his safe in late 1907 a financial
panic threatened to wreck the entire
country
Morgan summoned 50 leading bankers to
this room and told them they needed to
raise 25 million dollars between them
and walked out the door by 4:15 in the
morning no progress had been made the
Morgan came back in with an agreement
for each of them to sign sharing the
cost no one moved he walked over to the
first man and said here is the place and
here is the pen everyone signed
and then these great bronze doors were
opened Morgan had had the key in his
pocket they had all been locked in six
years later JP Morgan died his casket
came out these same bronze doors Frank
Vanderlip head of National City Bank
said the king is dead all New York is at
half-mast this building is his Monument
